1895-09-14 00:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know these are fine fruits, but 3 coins a kilogram is a bit steep for me.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
      Context for action selection and components
      • LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the fruit to someone else.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was tasked with helping his mother sell apples at the local market. The bustling crowds and boisterous haggling overwhelmed him, and he longed to retreat to the quiet solitude of their home. He watched as his mother effortlessly charmed customers, her voice lilting and her smile warm, and felt a deep sense of inadequacy.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he attempted to help his mother tend their small orchard, but the physical labor left him exhausted and discouraged. The thought of spending his days pruning branches and harvesting fruit filled him with a profound sense of dread. He retreated to the shade of a gnarled apple tree, dreaming of a life free from such toil.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he left his family home and set out on his own, determined to find a life of ease. He wandered from town to town, taking odd jobs, but nothing seemed to fit. He longed for a sense of purpose, but the thought of committing to anything felt overwhelming.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he stumbled upon a traveling merchant selling exotic fruits from distant lands. The vibrant colors and enticing aromas captivated him, and he saw a chance to escape the monotony of his life. He apprenticed himself to the merchant, hoping to find a semblance of freedom in the nomadic life.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know these are fine fruits, but 3 coins a kilogram is a bit steep for me.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:00:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market, negotiating with Lennon Figtree after purchasing it for one coin.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook could either accept Lennon Figtree's offer for the fruit or reject it.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the fruit to someone else.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

1895-09-14 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know these are fine fruits, but 3 coins a kilogram is a bit steep for me.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
      Context for action selection and components
      • LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to walk away from the deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they met a charismatic traveling salesman who taught them the art of storytelling and the power of persuasion. Lennon, eager to learn, absorbed every lesson like a sponge, quickly mastering the art of weaving elaborate tales to enhance the allure of their fruit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they traveled to a distant land, returning with exotic fruits never before seen in their hometown. The excitement and awe they generated upon their return solidified Lennon's belief that they were destined for greatness, a pioneer in the world of commerce.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, they experienced a rare moment of self-doubt. A rival merchant, known for their honesty and fair prices, began to draw customers away from Lennon's stall. For the first time, Lennon questioned their methods, wondering if their reliance on charm and theatricality was truly sustainable. This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know these are fine fruits, but 3 coins a kilogram is a bit steep for me.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:00:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook to resell in her hometown. Cedric is not happy with Lennon's initial offer.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Cedric Meadowbrook to lower his price, or Lennon Figtree could walk away from the deal.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to walk away from the deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is attempting to purchase fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market to resell in her hometown, but Cedric is dissatisfied with her initial offer.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is attempting to purchase fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook at the Fruitville market to resell in her hometown, but Cedric is dissatisfied with her initial offer.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they overheard two customers whispering about their father's fruit being overpriced. Hurt and confused, Lennon confronted them, their voice trembling with indignation. Their father, seeing the distress on Lennon's face, gently explained that while their prices might be higher, the quality of their fruit was unmatched. This lesson solidified Lennon's belief in their own superiority, convincing them that their charisma and charm were tools to be used to command the respect and admiration they deserved.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell fruit on their own. Armed with a wagon full of their finest produce and a head full of carefully crafted sales pitches, Lennon reveled in the independence and the power of making their own decisions. The success of the trip, coupled with the praise they received from strangers, further fueled Lennon's belief in their own exceptionalism.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they traveled to a distant land, returning with exotic fruits never before seen in their hometown. The excitement and awe they generated upon their return solidified Lennon's belief that they were destined for greatness, a pioneer in the world of commerce.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, they experienced a rare moment of self-doubt. A rival merchant, known for their honesty and fair prices, began to draw customers away from Lennon's stall. For the first time, Lennon questioned their methods, wondering if their reliance on charm and theatricality was truly sustainable. This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?

          State

        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they met a charismatic traveling salesman who taught them the art of storytelling and the power of persuasion. The excitement and awe they generated upon their return solidified Lennon's belief that they were destined for greatness, a pioneer in the world of commerce.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, they experienced a rare moment of self-doubt. A rival merchant, known for their honesty and fair prices, began to draw customers away from Lennon's stall. For the first time, Lennon questioned their methods, wondering if their reliance on charm and theatricality was truly sustainable. This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Cedric Meadowbrook to lower his price, or Lennon Figtree could walk away from the deal.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:00:00
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]
        ActComponent

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook to resell in her hometown. Cedric is not happy with Lennon's initial offer.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Cedric Meadowbrook to lower his price, or Lennon Figtree could walk away from the deal.

          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to walk away from the deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- 1 coin
    Event statement
  • 1 coin
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, they experienced a rare moment of self-doubt. A rival merchant, known for their honesty and fair prices, began to draw customers away from Lennon's stall. For the first time, Lennon questioned their methods, wondering if their reliance on charm and theatricality was truly sustainable. This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make a low offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell fruit on their own. The excitement and awe they generated upon their return solidified Lennon's belief that they were destined for greatness, a pioneer in the world of commerce.

This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic.         • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 23 years old, they experienced a rare moment of self-doubt. A rival merchant, known for their honesty and fair prices, began to draw customers away from Lennon's stall. For the first time, Lennon questioned their methods, wondering if their reliance on charm and theatricality was truly sustainable. This fleeting moment of vulnerability, however, was quickly dismissed as Lennon doubled down on their flamboyant persona, determined to prove their own superiority.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, I know these are fine fruits, but 3 coins a kilogram is a bit steep for me.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. That's a mite low, don't you think? These are fine apples, the best in the market.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, I know these are fine apples, but I'm a simple woman trying to make an honest living. I can offer you 4 coins for the lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I value your apples, but 5 coins is my final offer. Take it or leave it.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "That's not quite what I had in mind, Lennon.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook but is currently negotiating the price as she finds it too high.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, these ain't just any fruits. These are the finest specimens from Old Man Withers' orchard, grown with the purest spring water and kissed by the morning sun. You won't find this quality anywhere else in Fruitville.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.
          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00

        ActComponent

        • 1 coin
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the market in Fruitville trying to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook but is currently negotiating the price as she finds it too high.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make a low offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 3 coins
          (c) 1 coin
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (c)
        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer or reject it.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. They are much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In their view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of their decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what they already possess and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). They often prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, they would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. They are risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means they prefer a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. They often use mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking of it as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. They may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when they feel they are already in a losing position, they might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize their behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. They might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help them minimize losses and maintain their current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer.

          14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market but Lennon Figtree thinks his prices are too high. It is currently a little after midnight on September 14th, 1895.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the market but Lennon Figtree thinks his prices are too high. It is currently a little after midnight on September 14th, 1895.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he experienced the death of his father. The grief was overwhelming, and Cedric retreated further into himself, finding solace only in the quiet corners of his home. From then on, a shadow of melancholy seemed to follow him everywhere he went.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was tasked with helping his mother sell apples at the local market. The bustling crowds and boisterous haggling overwhelmed him, and he longed to retreat to the quiet solitude of their home. He watched as his mother effortlessly charmed customers, her voice lilting and her smile warm, and felt a deep sense of inadequacy.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he stumbled upon a traveling merchant selling exotic fruits from distant lands. The vibrant colors and enticing aromas captivated him, and he saw a chance to escape the monotony of his life. He apprenticed himself to the merchant, hoping to find a semblance of freedom in the nomadic life.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I can't let these beauties go for that price. How about 6 coins? It's a fair price for such fine fruit.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but I'm afraid that price is just too steep for me today. I'll have to pass.
